data.title: Kathleen Hanna Talks Punk Rock, Death, and Miley Cyrus
data.meta_description: Kathleen Hanna has new band called the Julie Ruin and a documentary called The Punk Singer coming out about her life. This seemed like a perfect time to talk with her about feminism, popular music, and her legacy.
data.text:
Kathleen Hanna performing with Bikini Kill in 1991, image via

Kathleen Hanna is, was, and always shall be a polarizing person. As the lead singer of the punk band Bikini Kill, her unapologetic views helped define the third wave of feminism in the 90s and spurred the Riot Grrrl movement. Kathleenâ€™s brazenness courted a great deal of critics who wanted to downplay the necessity of feminism; but as was customary for her, she continued to speak out against the male-dominated society with ferocity, and in the process became a reluctant but forceful spokesperson for her cause. After the demise of Bikini Kill, Kathleen recorded a solo album under the pseudonym Julie Ruin before forming the dance-punk band Le Tigre. The latter experienced a great deal of commercial success before Kathleen abruptly quit without explanation, leaving the spotlight without a trace.

Six years later, a documentary is being released about Kathleenâ€™s life. The Punk Singer chronicles her journey from an outspoken youth in Olympia up to her new band, the Julie Ruin. In the movie, she explains that her decision to stop performing in Le Tigre was due to late-onset Lyme disease, an illness that sapped all of her energy and left her feeling unable to do what she loves most. I sat down with Kathleen to ask her a few questions about punk rock, death, and what she thinks about Miley Cyrus calling herself a feminist.

VICE: Hey.

Kathleen Hanna: How are you doing today?

Terrible.

Do you want to talk about it?

No.

Are you sure?

Yes. I could get into it, but thereâ€™s no point. Iâ€™d tell you about working on a resume all day for some job at an ice skating rink, but that would make for rather boring commentary, wouldnâ€™t it? Iâ€™m failing to compete with 17-year-olds.

Bummer. Iâ€™ve been thinking about writing a resume. I was looking at being a teacher at the Clive Davis Institute of Recorded Music where I would help students improve their performance techniques. I kept thinking about how I would do that. I mean, what would I say? â€œHave charisma. You should all wear crowns.â€

Speaking of charisma, who is your favorite lead singer of Black Flag?

[Extremely long pause] I canâ€™t say. Whatâ€™s that one guyâ€™s name? See, I know Henry, butâ€¦ he wasnâ€™t my favorite. Heâ€™ll probably find out, but heâ€™s a nice guy and wonâ€™t care. So Iâ€™d say that first guy whose name I canâ€™t remember.

Yeah, if youâ€™d said Henry Rollins, I was planning on getting up and walking out of the room.

If you think about it, itâ€™s kind of unheard of for a good band to have more than one good lead singer. Actually, I almost tried out for the Misfits when they tried to reform. I think I have a total Misfits voice, and seriously, I could have done it. It was right at the tail end of Bikini Kill, and I was like, Do I keep doing Bikini Kill for the rest of the year or do I try out for the Misfits? I was convinced I was going to be picked.

It would have been badass.

It would have totally been badass! It would have changed the course of my history at least. If I showed up and it was all dudes, it would have been really funny. I would have stood out.

How do you feel about bands like the Dwarves?

Oh, the Dwarvesâ€¦ you know that album cover from Blood Guts & Pussy?

Yes.

Actually, do you know Corin Tucker? She was one of the singers from Sleater-Kinney and Heavens to Betsy, total Riot Grrrl bands from Olympia in the 90s. Corin had this really beautiful voice that made us all cry. But anyways, she was a 17 or 18-year-old college student making a video and she interviewed Bikini Kill and did not like us. She saw us as selfish because we were feminists and we were doing this thing that was pro-womenâ€”at least thatâ€™s what I felt when I first met her.

I watched her feelings about us change while we were doing the interview. She was actually listening to our ideas and was like, â€œWait a minute, Iâ€™m a feminist, I actually have felt these same kinds of thingsâ€¦â€ So she changed her movie to be about the cover of Blood Guts & Pussy. She interviewed all the female bands that were around the scene about it. Sheâ€™d hold up the cover and everyone would talk about it.

I was really offended by that album. We were in a scene that was so fucking male dominated and we were treated so poorly and that the album just sort of threw it in our faces. The whole thing was really anti-PC. If you read books about where that phrase came from, it was actually developed by a conservative think tank. Then it got used by people as a way to be racist or sexist or homophobic and absolve themselves from it. I do think there needs to be humor thatâ€™s uncontained, and I donâ€™t think everyone has to agree on everything, but I think itâ€™s important to understand the origins of the anti-PC movement.

With everything that was going on in the Northwest, I felt that Dwarves cover was simply shock for shock value. It was just to get attention, and it was at the expense of women. You know what I mean? Thereâ€™s a naked woman with blood all over her bodyâ€¦ and a dwarf? Like, why? [Laughs] It is an arresting image, Iâ€™ll give them that. You canâ€™t forget it once you see it, so something was going on there, but I felt they were just doing this â€œOh, weâ€™re just so fucked up and crazy and anti-PCâ€ thing.

Kathleen Hanna. Photo by Pat Smear.

That certainly seemed like part of it.

I knew so many men who wanted to get into arguments about feminism just because it was funny to them. Theyâ€™d be like, â€œIâ€™m just being a devilâ€™s advocate here,â€ and Iâ€™d say, â€œYou donâ€™t understand. I live this, and itâ€™s not funny to me.â€

How involved were you in the editing process of the movie? Were there things you wanted to get in there that didnâ€™t and vice versa?

I didnâ€™t craft the narrative, which was very weird. I just kept reminding myself that it was Sini and Tamaraâ€™s movie, and it was gonna be whatever they decided it was gonna be. I tried to be kind of tight lipped about it. I donâ€™t have any perspective on myself. You know, a lot of times before I go on stage Iâ€™ll ask my best friend Kathy what I should wear and Iâ€™ll just do it because I donâ€™t have any perspective on what looks good on me and what doesnâ€™t. I kind of had the same take on the movie. I didnâ€™t have any perspective on what my story is, so I just let them go at it.

The only things I was kind of freaked out about was a) that shitty spoken word at the beginning, which makes me cringe, and b) the one part where I talk about my mom, the trusting thing.

[Editorâ€™s Note: In the movie, Kathleen talks about her and her motherâ€™s somewhat sadistic relationship by describing a scene where the two play a trust game. Kathleen lets herself fall backwards expecting her mother to catch her, but instead her mother lets her fall to the ground. Lying there, she looked up to see her mother laughing. At this point her mother remarked, â€œLet that be a lesson to you. Donâ€™t trust anyone, not even your own mother.â€]

I told my therapist that story and she was like, â€œThatâ€™s so messed up, it explains why youâ€™re fucked up.â€ And I was laughing. Every time Iâ€™ve told that story Iâ€™ve laughed because I think itâ€™s very funny that a grown woman would do that to a child. My mom was the type of person who was always almost pointing at herself, saying, â€œWho let me be a mom?â€ She was cool and I always understood her sense of humor. So I made them add a voiceover of me saying something stupid like, â€œSheâ€™s actually really awesome and I love her a lot.â€ I had to put something in that didnâ€™t make it look like my mom was abusive, because she wasnâ€™t.

I thought that part was kind of cute and funny.

I do, too! Nobody else does.

I wrote something down like, â€œI wish somebody had taught me that lesson before I met my ex-girlfriend.â€

Donâ€™t trust anyone, not even your own mom.

Hereâ€™s a question nobody wanted me to ask you: What do you think about death?

Oh, thatâ€™s a great question. I think itâ€™s like a portal that you can go through to get out if you want, and itâ€™s in every roomâ€”at least I see it in every room. That doesnâ€™t mean Iâ€™m suicidal, it just means thereâ€™s always an escape route. Maybe thatâ€™s totally fucked up, but I think death is an escape route if you need it. Itâ€™s like an eject button. But Iâ€™m a control freak, so I always see myself as the one who makes the decision in the end. But thatâ€™s a really weird question because I honestly do see it as a tunnel.

I wonder how thatâ€™s going to read?

Just draw a picture of a hole in a wall.

How often do you think about death?

Well, not as much as I used to, but when I was sick I thought about it all the time. Thatâ€™s when the portal ideas started going in my head. When youâ€™re in an extreme amount of pain constantly, you become a totally different person. You start thinking to yourself, How can I make this stop? I was taking all this medication, marijuana pills, anything to make it stop, and it wasnâ€™t working. So Iâ€™m like, thereâ€™s one way that I can make this stop. I had to believe that at some point I could make it through it, but knowing the portal was there was very helpful. I felt if it came down to it, I could make that choice.

I heard you say on NPR that youâ€™re just as angry as before, but youâ€™ve managed to direct it better. What pisses you off now?

You. [Laughs]

Do you still feel like youâ€™re being attacked?

Noâ€”and you donâ€™t make me angry, I just thought it was a funny thing to say. Things have really come around. People have been super cool. I feel like I got a lot of shit in the 90s from all sides, from asshole feminists who resented me and the attention I was getting, from dudes who didnâ€™t want the punk scene to include women, from asshole journalists who just talked about our butts and what we were wearing, to people who wrote fanzines and wrote that same shit. Whatâ€™s the difference between the mainstream and the underground if the fanzines are writing the same exact stuff Rolling Stone is writing?

I feel 20 years later, people are like, â€œWow, that mattered, that was cool,â€ and Iâ€™m getting the kind of positive attention that I didnâ€™t get back then. So when people are like, â€œOh, thatâ€™s just nostalgia, thatâ€™s why people care about the grunge scene,â€ Iâ€™m like, â€œI donâ€™t give a shit.â€ I just like feeling appreciated because at the time we werenâ€™t appreciated, and people would throw shit at our heads while we were playing, and it was really, really hard. So Iâ€™m stoked.

The Julie Ruinâ€™s song â€œGirls Like Usâ€ reminds me of â€œTypical Girlsâ€ from the Slitsâ€¦

Yes, but, I think â€œTypical Girlsâ€ is more making fun of girls who read magazines, put lipstick on, and stuff like that. I never liked that divide. I never liked the whole â€œweâ€™re the cool girls who play music and youâ€™re the stupid girls who go to the mall,â€ because I was the stupid girl who went to the mall and then later got into music. I feel like â€œGirls Like Usâ€ is a statement that thereâ€™s no unity. And there shouldnâ€™t be unity. There are no â€œgirls like us.â€ All the shit in that song is totally abstract and doesnâ€™t make any sense, and I guess in a lot of ways that is a tribute to the Slits. A lot of Ariâ€™s lyrics were pretty fucking weirdâ€¦ She was a fucking weird person.

Miley Cyrus recently called herself one of the biggest feminists in the world. Is she?

I love that. I have no idea. What do you think?

I donâ€™t know.

I donâ€™t know either. I mean, I feel like itâ€™s cool that sheâ€™s this young girl that calls herself a feminist, butâ€¦ do we want her in our club? [Laughs] Have you seen the new Lily Allen video? Iâ€™d suggest you watch that.
